meanings.definition: To give someone the right to do or have something.
meanings.sent1: The teacher will entitle you to extra recess time for good behavior.
meanings.sent2: Winning the contest will entitle you to a prize.
meanings.sent3: Being the birthday child entitles you to choose the game we play.
meanings.sent4: Hard work and dedication will entitle you to success in the long run.
meanings.sent5: Earning a degree will entitle you to better job opportunities.

meanings.definition: To give a title to a book, movie, etc.
meanings.sent1: The author will entitle her new book 'The Adventures of Lily'.
meanings.sent2: The film director decided to entitle the movie 'The Mystery of Midnight Manor'.
meanings.sent3: The artist chose to entitle his painting 'Sunset Serenity'.
meanings.sent4: The poet entitles her latest collection 'Whispers of the Heart'.
meanings.sent5: The playwright will entitle the play 'A Tale of Two Cities'.

meanings.definition: To believe that you have the right to something.
meanings.sent1: She felt entitled to the last piece of cake since it was her birthday.
meanings.sent2: Some people entitle themselves to privileges without earning them.
meanings.sent3: He jokingly entitles himself to the title of 'King of the Kitchen'.
meanings.sent4: The wealthy businessman entitles himself to luxury vacations every year.
meanings.sent5: The arrogant actor entitles himself to special treatment on set.
